summary.p: Single folio Qurʾān fragment on parchment; Shelfmark KFQ 49; 21 lines per page; Script style kūfī type C.Ia influenced by ḥiǧāzī IV and the early kūfī script style B.I;
Another three fragments BnF Arabe 332 from Paris, Vat.ar.1784 from Vatican and fol. 1 of E 16264 D from Pennsylvania University Museum originally belonged to the same codex.

In his catalogue from 1992 F. Déroche gives no estimate date of production of KFQ 49 and labels the script of the fragment as 'unclassified' (See Déroche 1992: p. 129), although in his early publication about the BnF collection Déroche classifies the script of the sister fragment Arabe 332 "to be close" to C.Ia (See Déroche 1983: p. 77). The connection of the script of the codex with early script styles such as ḥiǧāzī IV and the kūfī script style B.I suggest the dating between 700 and 800 CE. The absence of the vocalisation and a very scarce usage of the diacritical signs also speak for an early date.

F. Déroche writes about the fragment (The Abbasid Tradition, London 1992, S. 129): "71 / Single folio / Undated / Fragmentary (largest dimensions now 30x30.5 cm); parts of 18 lines survive / Material Parchment; the verso is the hair side / Text area 27.1x30 cm / Script Unclassified / Accession no. KFQ 49 / Another fragment from the same Qurʾan / Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale, MS.arab.332 (Déroche 1983, no.47) / Some letter forms seen here - alif and mīm, for example - resemble those of C.Ia, but others, such as nūn, are only remotely connected to this style. The text runs from Sūrat al-taghābun (LXIV), verse 15, to Sūrat al-ṭalāq (LXV), verse 10, with a lacuna at surah LXV, verses 2-4. It is written in brown ink, with occasional diacritical strokes but no vocalization. Clusters of oblique strokes (I.I.I) mark the ends of verses. The surah title has been added in cursive script."

supportDesc.support: Text division: The group of three oblique dashes mark the end of a verse. Every tenth verse is marked by a circle filled with red ink with a dot in the center. Sūrahs were originally separated with a blank space, a later hand writes the Sūrah title and the number of verses in a cursive hand in black ink. Other two sister fragments Arabe 332 and Vat.ar.1784 show the same separation of the verses and Sūrahs. The cursive hand that writes the title of the Sūrahs and the number of verses seem to be the same in all three fragments.

summary.p: This manuscript represents a script style close to kūfī type C.Ia influenced by the early kūfī script style B.I and ḥiǧāzī IV. The letter ʾalif resembles the C.Ia group. Within a word, the letters ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ cross the base line diagonally (not after a denticle) as those of B.I group, unlike those of C.Ia, where the letter rests on the base line. The tail of the letter in the final position is horizontal as those of C.Ia. The letter ʿayn in the initial position is close to C.Ia but shows an interesting form of the upper hook: the hook has a rounded shape that looks like a dot, that cannot be seen in any other script groups. Within a word the letter resembles the B.Ib group, the right hand antenna being vertical. The final form of the letter is identical to those seen in the D.IV group, but is also close to the B.I/B.II group. The letter qāf isolated or in the final position is similar to those of C.Ia group. The initial and medial forms of the letter hāʾ, alongside with the letter nūn in the final or isolated position and the letter mīm at the end of a word show a similar form seen in the ḥiǧāzī IV manuscript Saray 50385 from Istanbul, the script of which also shows similarities to the C.Ia group. As for the ligature lām-ʾalif, the form is similar to the C.Ia group.

F. Déroche relates the script of the sister fragment BnF Arabe 332 to the C.Ia group (See Déroche 1983: p. 77). The script of the fragment KFQ 49 is categorized by Déroche as 'unclassified', although he links the manuscript with BnF Arabe 332 (See Déroche 1992: p. 129).
The manuscript shows occasional diacritical marking, but no signs of vocalisation.
